mxCell.value:
<<Accounts>>

Let's go over the lay of the land. 

This is the Accounts view. On the left you will see all the accounts you add to MBC, and on the right you will see all the transactions in each account.

This is the view that you will use when inputting, categorizing, and reconciling transactions. 

Now let's head to the Budget.

You can click here at any time to book a call with me. 

FYI - There is an additional hourly fee for these calls. While I'd love to see you, I made this avatar so you wouldn't need to set up a call in most cases and you can save those dollars for something else!
move_to: zoom_link
Let's do it!

<<Accounts>>

Here is what we will be covering.

1. Account Setup
2. How to Add Transactions
3. Budget Tour & Setup
4. Budget Skills
5. Trusting Your Numbers by Reconciling

Database - can keep responses and reference later on; not all questions need the database capture. The second line of the response selected is the database code. If not planning to reference answer later or drive flow based on response in another section, don't need second line.

<<Accounts>> / <<Budget>>

This aligns the avatar with which screen the user should be on. If a user goes to the Budget at a step where the avatar flow has <<Accounts>>, or if the user goes to an Account while the avatar is on Budget, the user will see the following message:

 Please navigate to the Accounts {Budget} to continue our conversation (please select an account).

Please Note: There needs to be a blank line between the reference to Accounts/Budget and the text shown in the avatar window.
Buttons can be short, default to 'Next' no text added on line, or even two sentences. Can also have multiple selections if asking a question.
Link to giphy: https://giphy.com/gifs/film-vintage-UDjF1zMreMld6

Welcome to MyBudgetCoach [[user_first_name]]! 

MyBudgetCoach is a unique, zero based budgeting software that comes along with a virtual avatar. 

You selected, me, Jacqueline, as your personal coach. I believe budgeting can be fun and bring you confidence and a sense of peace, calm, and control in your life. Let's do it!
Are you budgeting with a partner?

YES
partner = yes

NO
partner = no
Nice, you get full control over the budget.
Next<br style="border-color: var(--border-color);">partner_name = [user_input]
Awesome, I love team work. I'm glad you are jumping in together. What is their name?
I look forward to working with you and [[partner_name]].
Hell yeah!

<<Accounts>>

I love to name my budget something that makes me smile when I log in. I highly recommend something silly, inspiring, or funny. Emojis encouraged. 

Click on the name of the budget, and then click on Rename Budget to give yours a great name.
move_to: budget_name

<<Accounts>>

I hope you picked something good. If not, you can always change it later!

Next, we're going to add your first account. Exciting!
move_to: center_screen
Account Setup Process

<<Accounts>>

I highly recommend setting up the connection that will bring in your transactions automatically. To do that, choose "Link bank account with SimpleFIN". It costs an additional $1.50 a month, but it is so, so, SO worth it.

If you don't want to do that, you will choose "Create Local Account". Name your account and then enter the current balance of that account as your starting balance.

<<Accounts>>

Ready? Select + Add Account!

<<Accounts>>

Go to your checking account web page, write down the current balance, then come back here and click Next.

NO
credit_cards = no

<<Accounts>>

Let's keep going. Do you have credit cards that you use regularly?
No thanks, I'll do it manually.

YES
credit_cards = yes

<<Accounts>>

Awesome, let's continue on to the next step!
move_to: add_account
Budget Summary Overview

<<Budget>>

I love budgeting. I know this makes me sound weird, but budgeting gives me control over my life. I know what I can spend and when, so I no longer feel confused about what I have, or shame about spending. 

I want you to feel the same control!

<<Budget>>

I'll give you a tour of your budget screen. Here you can see the current month as well as previous and future months.

<<Budget>>

Let's say you want to compare several months at once. Depending on your browser zoom level, you can select up to six months at a time. 

Try clicking on the different calendar icons to see the different views, and then leave it on viewing just one month for now (no reason to get too complicated right off the bat! =))
move_to: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

Try changing the view so you can see a different set of months using the purple selection. 

Make sure to select the current month when you are done exploring!
move_to: months_band

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget."
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

While you're getting to know MyBudgetCoach, just focus on the amount to budget for now.

<<Budget>>

Click on the purple (or red if it is negative) number to see some options for this amount. There are multiple ways to move money around your budget. After all, it's meant to be flexible!

<<Budget>>

Let's move onto the next part!
Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This budget table is basically a digital cash envelope system. You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll customize these in a bit.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Take a look at the three dots next to the Category header. When you click on this, it gives you visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide Hidden categories.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. You have options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Try adding a sample category. Click the arrow again and add a category - anything you like, we're going to delete it.

<<Budget>>

Nicely done - you'll get the hang of it in no time.
Add Transaction

<<Accounts>>

Next up, let's practice adding a transaction on your checking account. It's not that scary, don't worry. Click on your checking account to get started!

<<Accounts>>

For checking account transactions, payments DECREASE the balance and deposits INCREASE the balance.

Payments = Outflow
Deposits = Inflow

<<Accounts>>

Click "+ Add New"...
move_to: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

For the category, select "Food".

<<Accounts>>

 Now, click "Add". You can hit "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance has decreased by $100.
move_to: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Let's delete this pretend transaction. Go ahead and hover on the left side of the date to un-hide a box. Select the box to select the transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Nice work! It's time to move on to the fun part - the Budget! 🎉

<<Accounts>>

On the right hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options.

Select 'Delete' to remove that transaction.

If you love keyboard shortcuts, you can just press 'D' to delete a selected transaction.

This Account Set-Up section could be expanded. Could ask the user questions related to how many checking accounts / how many credit cards / the type of account structure the user has (joint / separate / single...)

The template has 
just one 'adding a transaction' example. However, you as the coach could use the credit cards question from before, to use the database to have additional sections for a credit card transaction, and walking through how a transfer (payment to a credit card) works in the bank account and credit card.
Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.
Coach should consider adding a flow for walking a user through how to link accounts with SimpleFin. Consult with Coach Trainers if interested in sample flow.
Consider having a question to create a break for the user. Could also reference the earlier list of steps to complete, and show progress by crossing out those pieces that are done.
Insert wrap-up
<font style="font-size: 12px;">...one last thing before I leave you to your budgeting...</font>
You got it 👍🏻
<font style="font-size: 12px;">Can you answer 3 short questions for me? I want to make sure I continue to improve how helpful I am!</font>
I submitted the form
Great! Here's the link: https://airtable.com/appYAaDkGzB3ecOzl/shrUnpE9sHBWWDMyB
<font style="font-size: 12px;">Thanks so much! Happy budgeting!</font>
User Survey after Tutorial
Credit Card Overview
Budget Skills

<<Budget>>

You did it! You successfully created a budget. I hope it was not as bad as you feared, and maybe even a little fun...maybe? 🤓

<<Budget>>

If you are struggling with your budget and would like some one on one help, please feel free to book a call with me at this link. I'd love to meet you in real life!

People who have Credit Card balances in excess of their available dollars in their checking account will have a negative amount To Budgeted. This is an important step for the user, but can be handled in a various number of ways. Consider the main steps the user needs to complete, and then determine as the coach if you want to add more detail for any of those steps:

1) Adding the Credit Card Category Group
2) Add a Category for each Credit Card
3) Changing the category on the account side of the Credit Card starting balance to the newly created Category
4) Rollover overspending if not going to pay off balance

This will give the user back their dollars in their checking account in the To Budgeted.

delete_category_group: Usual Expenses
delete_category_group: Investments and Savings
create_category_group: Fixed
create_category_group: Flexible + Fun
create_category_group: Savings
create_category: Fixed: Rent
create_category: Fixed: Utilities
create_category: Fixed: Subscriptions
create_category: Fixed: Medical
create_category: Fixed: Transportation
create_category: Flexible + Fun: Spending Money
create_category: Flexible + Fun: Groceries
create_category: Flexible + Fun: Eating Out
create_category: Flexible + Fun: Personal Care
create_category: Savings: Emergency Fund 
create_category: Savings: Travel
create_category: Savings: Home Items
create_category: Savings: Gifts
create_category: Savings: Retirement
Budget Setup

You as the Coach can do as much or as little as you would like for the user. For example, if you just want to add a handful of categories, or walk them through how to edit and add themselves, that is fine. Alternatively, you could have the system build an entire budget with defined groups, and categories, so when they select the button before the template is built, it automatically updates.

<<Budget>>

Take a moment to look them over, remove any that don't apply to you, and add anything that is missing. 

Don't worry about getting everything in now - your budget is a living document that will be updated regularly and you can always make changes.
No 😰

<<Budget>>

Take some time to look over the categories one more time and make any changes you feel you need right now. 

Don't worry about putting money anywhere just yet =)

<<Budget>>

Love that for you! Ok friend, the time has come...to budget! 🎉

Before we get started, 
quick note: if you need to undo something, press Control + Z on a PC or Command + Z on a Mac, or use the Undo and Redo buttons at the top of the Category list.
All done!

<<Budget>>

Once the number at the top is $0, go ahead and move forward!
Don't Edit - Keep link and keep text

This is the end of the tutorial. Your coach avatar will come back if you program a trigger. Once you are a launched coach, reach out to Coach Trainers for additional steps to set-up a trigger for your avatar to re-join the user at certain times.

For example, 15th and 31st of the month to verify Budgeted down to $0 newly received income.

<<Budget>>

No problem. The important thing is that we need to reflect that debt in your budget accurately so you can trust your numbers. 

I've added a category group named "Credit Cards". with a sample 'Card One'. Rename Card One with your actual card name and add additional categories for each credit card you carry a balance on in that group.
Now that you have added a category for each of your cards, it’s time to account for your current debt in your budget. Go ahead and click on a credit card account on the left.

<<Accounts>>

See that first transaction with the category of “Starting Balance”? Go ahead and change the category to the credit card that matches this account. 

Once you have saved the transaction, click back to the Budget.

<<Budget>>

Now go to the applicable category - see how the amount in the Available category is red? Click the red number and then click Rollover Overspending.

(You may need to click the 'x' to the left of my avatar picture to see this part of your budget. You can do that and then click on 'Continue Conversation' on the left sidebar to pick back up =).)

COMING SOON:

Template flow for linking accounts via SimpleFIN.

<<Budget>>

This is the Budget view. You'll make all your budgeting decisions on this screen.

While I wish I could be right there next to you to answer your questions, this little avatar I made is going to do it's best to be there for you every step of the way. Unfortunately you can't ask the avatar questions, but if you need additional one on one help, you can set up a call!

<<Accounts>>

We're going to go over the Accounts view first.

Keep in mind - if you start to get overwhelmed, don't panic. Money is a stressful area and emotions are bound to come up throughout this process. There is no shame in taking a break to dance it out, call a friend, watch cute animal videos, or whatever you like. I'll always be here when you are ready to pick up again. =)

<<Accounts>>

Do you have another checking or savings account?

<<Accounts>>

Great - select + Add Account again to add it.

<<Accounts>>

Now you'll login to your credit card site or app to get the current balance. Come back when you're done, I'll wait. 🍿

<<Accounts>>

Woohoo! Select + Add Account again to add it, and either enter your balance as the Starting Balance, or confirm it is correct with the information imported.

<<Accounts>>

Do you have another credit card?

<<Accounts>>

Great - select + Add Account again to add it.

<<Budget>>

Now hover over the new category with your mouse, click the arrow, and delete the category you just created.

<<Budget>>

If you'd like I can add some usual budget categories for you. I like to separate spending into Fixed, Flexible & Fun, and Savings. Do you want to try them out?
No thanks

<<Budget>>

Do you have debt to repay?
Yes 😅

<<Budget>>

No sweat. I have debt too!

I've added a few categories that might cover your situation. Again, feel free to remove or add anything!

create_category_group: Debt
create_category_group: Credit Cards
create_category: Debt: Student Loans
create_category: Debt: Personal Loan
create_category: Debt: Back Taxes
create_category: Debt: Mortgage

<<Budget>>

Nice! Don't mind me, I'm just a little jealous 😉

create_category_group: Credit Cards
create_category: Credit Cards: Card One

<<Budget>>

A hypothetical for you - if you needed to pay off your entire credit card balance(s) right now, could you do it without sweating?
Hell yeah, no sweat
highlight: budget_header

<<Budget>>

The good news is that the actual budgeting itself is pretty simple. Our goal is to get this number to $0 by assigning dollars to the categories below.

<<Budget>>

I recommend starting with your Fixed expenses - since those have to be paid! - and work your way down through Flexible & Fun, Debt, and finally Savings. 

Note - if you have credit card categories, make sure you budget at least the minimum payment for each card.
Yes, this is me, I'm panicking

<<Budget>>

Cool, no stress! You got this!

If the number is red, that means you need to reduce the amount of dollars assigned in your categories until it is $0 again.

<<Budget>>

If you don't have enough to fund everything, think of it this way: What does this money need to do until I get paid again?

<<Budget>>

You may find as you go along that you run out of dollars to assign and this number turns red. Zero based budgeting can be a shock to folks who have been a bit unaware of their financial situation.

If this happens to you and you start to panic, take a few minutes to take a break, dance it out, go for a walk, or whatever calms your nervous system. I'll be here when you get back.
I'm cool as a cucumber

<<Budget>>

Glad to hear it! Once you're done budgeting your dollars and the number up top is $0, you can move forward.
All done!

<<Budget>>

If you need to find money, look first to the Flexible & Fun categories, and then the Savings.

<<Budget>>

If you start to feel any shame or guilt, try to remember that these numbers are not a reflection of who you are or of your worth. They are just numbers and you are taking the important first step of trying to figure them out and take control - that's great!

<<Budget>>

I recommend logging into your budget  daily to categorize transactions, and to reconcile each account weekly to make sure all the numbers are accurate. 

By staying connected to your budget, you will always know what is available and what needs protecting!
highlight: zoom_link
move_to: zoom_link
highlight: budget_table
highlight: category_column
highlight: budgeted_column
highlight: spent_column
highlight: balance_column

<<Budget>>

Cool. Go ahead and add the  categories you want! You can click on the little 'x' next to my picture to get me out of your way for now, and then you can click "Continue Conversation" in the left side bar when you are ready to pick back up!

<<Budget>>

Ok friend, the time has come...to budget! 🎉

Before we get started, 
quick note: if you need to undo something, press Control + Z on a PC or Command + Z on a Mac, or use the Undo and Redo buttons at the top of the Category list.

Sounds good. You deserve a break, we just covered a ton of info!!

Go ahead and click on the little x to the left of my photo to hide me for now, and click on me again when you are ready to do more! Our next step is learning to reconcile your accounts =).
How are you feeling? Do you need a break, or are you ready to learn more?
I’d like a break, please.

Awesome! Next up, we’re going to learn how to reconcile our accounts. 

Reconciling is how we make sure that your account balance in MBC matches your account balance in real life. If they don’t match, you can’t trust your budget - and that sucks. So let’s go to the Accounts view and learn how to reconcile!
I’m ready for more!

<<Accounts>>

Choose your checking account and click on the three dots to the far right, then click on Reconcile.
Ready to go?

<<Accounts>>

Enter your current checking account balance in the box that pops up, and then click Reconcile.
Go ahead and do the same process with the next account.

<<Accounts>>

Does the message at the top center say “All Reconciled! in green?

Amazing! You can click Done Reconciling.

Do you have another account to reconcile?

Ok, don’t panic. The next step is to compare the transactions from your bank to the transactions in MBC. Go ahead and find the list of recent transactions from your bank on their site or in their app.

<font style="font-size: 12px;">If the transactions all match but the balances don’t, click on Create Reconciliation Transaction. MBC will enter a transaction that will force the balance to match your bank so you can trust your numbers.  </font>
Compare the transactions from the bank with the transactions in MBC. Do they all match?

If you see some transactions that don’t match, make sure to add any missing ones to MBC, and remove any ones that are in MBC but not in your bank. 

Once they all match, click Next.
Does the green “All Reconciled!” Message show at the top now?
Awesome, great job! Reconciling can be difficult, but it is much easier if you do it often. I recommend at least once a week.

Now look at the little check marks on the far right of each transaction.

When the transaction has ‘cleared’, or ‘posted’ in your bank account, you should click the checkbox to turn it green. 

If the transaction is still pending, leave the checkbox gray.
Still no! WTF
Yes, finally!
Yep, everything is the same!
No, I see some differences.
Nope, all done!
highlight: more_button
Ok, I clicked it!
Thanks for sharing [[user_first_name]].

<<Accounts>>

...and type "Restaurant" as your Payee.

move_to: select_category

<<Accounts>>

Now, enter $100 in the Payment box..

If you look at the account balance now, you'll see it has increased by $100.

<<Budget>>

You can see your total income for the month, as well as the starting balance at the very bottom.

Great! Check out the set up video here: https://shorturl.at/fkz05
Do you want to use SimpleFIN?

move_to: select_category

By rolling over the spending, you will be able to carry the balance from month to month while you pay it off over time. 


But don’t worry - you’ll be paying these cards off in no time!

<<Accounts>>

Now let's say you want to enter a transaction for when you make a transfer between accounts, or you make a payment on a credit card.

<<Accounts>>

Go ahead and add the transaction the same way as before, but when you are choosing the Payee, select 'Make Transfer'.

<<Accounts>>

Now you should see a list of your other accounts to choose from. Choose the correct account, and then make sure you accurately reflect whether money is going out of this account (Payment) or into this account (Deposit).

<<Accounts>>

You'll also notice that you no longer need to choose a Category for this transaction - this is because the money is not leaving the budget, it's just getting moved around. 

If this doesn't make perfect sense to you right now, don't stress. It will make more sense after you have used MBC for awhile!

<<Accounts>>

Go ahead and delete this sample transaction now.

Click on the purple number to see some options for this amount. There are multiple ways to move money around your budget. After all, it's meant to be flexible!

Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll get customizing these in a bit.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Take a look at these three dots. This gives you visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide Hidden categories.

To the right hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options.

Select 'Delete' to remove that transaction.

This Account Set-Up section could be expanded. Could ask the user questions related to how many checking accounts / how many credit cards / the type of account structure the user has (joint / separate / single...)

The template has 
just one 'adding a transaction' example. However, you as the coach could use the credit cards question from before, to use the database to have additional sections for a credit card transaction, and walking through how a transfer (payment to a credit card) works in the bank account and credit card.
Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.
Coach should consider adding a flow for walking a user through how to link accounts with SimpleFin. Consult with Coach Trainers if interested in sample flow.
Consider having a question to create a break for the user. Could also reference the earlier list of steps to complete, and show progress by crossing out those pieces that are done.

Coach option to offer email for users to contact you directly prior to a call. Could help with triaging if a call is needed, versus hopping on a call and then realizing there isn't enough information.

People who have Credit Card balances in excess of their available dollars in their checking account will have a negative amount To Budgeted. This is an important step for the user, but can be handled in a various number of ways. Consider the main steps the user needs to complete, and then determine as the coach if you want to add more detail for any of those steps:

1) Adding the Credit Card Category Group
2) Add a Category for each Credit Card
3) Changing the category on the account side of the Credit Card starting balance to the newly created Category
4) Rollover overspending if not going to pay off balance

This will give the user back their dollars in their checking account in the To Budgeted.

<<Budget>>

create_category_group: Monthly Bills
create_category: Monthly Bills: 🏠 Rent/Mortgage (1st)

Insert as many as you would like using the create_... Delete_....
Budget Setup

You as the Coach can do as much or as little as you would like for the user. For example, if you just want to add a handful of categories, or walk them through how to edit and add themselves, that is fine. Alternatively, you could have the system build an entire budget with defined groups, and categories, so when they select the button before the template is built, it automatically updates.

This is the end of the tutorial. Your coach avatar will come back if you program a trigger. Once you are a launched coach, reach out to Coach Trainers for additional steps to set-up a trigger for your avatar to re-join the user at certain times.

For example, 15th and 31st of the month to verify Budgeted down to $0 newly received income.
